entry.title: Building Trust in AI: SAP Business AI earns ISO/IEC 42001 Certification
entry.content:
Artificial intelligence is reshaping how businesses operate, innovate, and serve their customers. But as AI becomes more deeply embedded into enterprise systems, ensuring that it behaves responsibly is just as important as making it powerful. 

That’s why we’re proud to share that SAP Business AI has achieved ISO/IEC 42001:2023 certification — the world’s first international standard for Artificial Intelligence Management Systems (AIMS). 
This certification covers Joule, SAP AI Core, and SAP AI Launchpad, reinforcing SAP’s long-standing commitment to building trustworthy, transparent, and ethical AI across our products and services. 

Why This Matters 

Responsible AI isn’t just a principle. It’s a prerequisite for scaling AI safely in enterprise environments. The ISO/IEC 42001 standard provides a structured framework that guides how organizations manage AI across strategy, governance, data, compliance, and sustainability. 

For SAP, this certification validates that our approach to AI meets globally recognized standards for fairness, accountability, reliability, and security. It means our customers and partners can rely on SAP AI solutions that are developed, deployed, and maintained with integrity. 

What the Certification Covers 

The certification recognizes SAP’s efforts to embed responsible AI practices throughout the entire AI lifecycle: 

  • Establishing a comprehensive AI Management System (AIMS) aligned with ISO 42001. 
  • Integrating AI security, ethics, and compliance controls at every stage of AI development. 
  • Enabling cross-functional collaboration among engineering, legal, governance, and compliance teams. 
  • Successfully passing an independent third-party audit that assessed SAP’s operational excellence in AI governance. 

The certification scope includes Joule, SAP AI Core, and SAP AI Launchpad, along with SAP’s internal IT processes and AI governance policies. 

Responsible AI in Practice 

The ISO 42001 certification underscores that SAP Business AI is built on the foundation of responsible AI. 
In practice, this means: 

  • Fairness and Transparency: AI results are explainable, unbiased, and clearly communicated to end users. 
  • Reliability and Security: AI models are developed and deployed with robust safeguards around data use, access, and protection. 
  • Ethical Alignment: Every AI solution undergoes an ethics evaluation to ensure consistency with SAP’s sustainability and compliance goals. 
  • Continuous Adaptability: Governance and risk management evolve as new technologies and regulations emerge. 

Benefits for Our Ecosystem 

For customers and partners, this milestone brings clear advantages: 

  • Confidence that SAP AI systems are developed and managed under a certified, globally recognized framework. 
  • Reduced compliance burden through alignment with international and regional AI regulations. 
  • Stronger data integrity and security safeguards that protect sensitive business information. 
  • The ability to demonstrate responsible AI usage within their own operations and industries. 

Even for SAP teams, the ISO 42001 certification is more than a badge of compliance. It has been a powerful catalyst for collaboration. It’s brought together experts in technology, policy, and compliance to strengthen how we design, test, and deliver AI. This shared framework helps us innovate faster and smarter, with accountability built into every step. 

A Step Toward the Future 

The ISO/IEC 42001:2023 certification is a key milestone in SAP’s ongoing commitment to responsible AI and customer success. It strengthens the foundation we’ve built to ensure every advancement in SAP Business AI delivers innovation with integrity. 

As AI evolves, so will SAP’s dedication to keeping it reliable, transparent, and aligned with our customers’ trust and business goals. 

Learn more about SAP Business AI and how we’re shaping the future of responsible enterprise AI.

entry.title: SAP User Experience Update: What’s New for SAP S/4HANA 2025 (Private Cloud and On-Premise)
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA 2025 comes with a whole host of user experience innovations and improvements.  Web access via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad has many useful improvements, as does SAP Mobile Start for mobile access. Joule gives conversational access to Private Cloud Edition using natural language, now also with analytical insights. There are additional collaboration capabilities, and many improvements in details: some towards providing a more consistent and integrated SAP Business Suite, some simply making a user’s life easier. Finally, design and UI technology is also advancing, with powerful AI support for developers now available.

This post covers:

  • UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite
  • Web access: My Home and SAP Fiori launchpad
  • Mobile access: SAP Mobile Start
  • Joule
  • Situation Handling news
  • AI-Assisted capabilities: outlook
  • New collaboration capabilities
  • UX improvements in details
  • UI adaptation improvements for key users
  • Design and Technology news

If you want to get an impression of how good SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, looks across all the main product areas, have a look at the online Product Tour.

Since this post covers what’s new, building on the previous 2023 release, you might want to have a look at the UX innovations which came with the Feature Pack Stacks 00, 01 and 02 of the 2023 release:

  • SAP User Experience Update: What’s New for SAP S/4HANA 2023 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • User Experience Advances with SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • SAP User Experience Q4/2024 News for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023.

For a full overview of what’s new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the documentation (note that it includes features from the above 2023 FPS01 and FPS02 blog posts, as well as this one):

  • What’s New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite

We aim to provide a consistent and integrated experience for all users of the SAP Business Suite, which means providing an entry point for users to access all the various SAP products within the suite, and ensuring that the user experience across these products is consistent, making it easy for users to use applications from different products.

Entry Points

Figure 1 shows our approach for providing a web and a native mobile entry point to the products of the suite, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud. I’d like to highlight that Joule can also be seen as an entry point to access the entire suite, since our goal is to provide Joule wherever you are, be it in our web applications or native mobile apps. Using Joule, our goal is to allow users to query and perform actions on all the products and applications which they are authorized to use, simply using natural language. As you’ll see below, we are making good progress towards this goal.

Figure 1: Entry points providing an integrated workplace for accessing the SAP Business Suite. Alt Text: Image showing Joule on the left, “available web and mobile”, and on the right a diagram with boxes indicating that SAP Mobile Start, SAP Start, and SAP Build Work Zone provide central access to SAP, with three boxes below for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors and Other SAP Products.

Web Central Access

I have covered recent UX innovations in our web central entry points, such as SAP Start and SAP Build Work Zone, and central services such as SAP Task Center, in my recent cloud UX blog posts. Since these capabilities also apply to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition as well as SAP S/4HANA (except for SAP Start), I will not repeat them here, but rather refer you to them:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update – Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

 What we will look at in this post in detail are UX innovations for local access from web or mobile, via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad, and via SAP Mobile Start. Each has a dedicated section further below.

Design Updates for Suite Consistency

To achieve consistency across the suite, we have made design improvements which are relevant for a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite, and which are now available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025. As I mentioned in my April blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products – no unexpected surprises.

In this section, we’ll look at four design updates provided by the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as examples of the new design for illustrations:

  • Navigation menu: Side navigation
  • Updated shell bar
  • Updated user menu
  • Updated notifications
  • New illustrations design

Navigation Menu: Side Navigation

Many SAP products already offer a navigation menu on the left of the screen, a pattern already familiar to many people. Hence, we have decided to apply that approach to navigation across the SAP Business Suite in upcoming releases.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, the side navigation is displayed as an overlay, as you can see in Figure 2. It gives you direct access to your favorite apps, either directly or via the folders you have created. It also gives you direct access to your Spaces and Pages. The previously available menu to access all your spaces and pages along with personalization options is available via the entry “All Spaces” at the bottom of the menu.

A big benefit of this new navigation menu is that you can now access your favorite apps directly from any application. Previously, you would have to return to My Home and then click on your favorite app, now you can access it directly from the menu, as shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2: The new navigation menu, opened up from the new shell bar, showing direct access to Favourite Apps, My Spaces and All Spaces. Alt Text: an image showing a list of sales orders and on the left a pop-over with a navigation menu with the sections already mentioned. Below the “Favourite App” eight apps are listed as well as two folders for favorite apps, plus the folder “Insights” for the insight tiles.

New Shell Bar – need to switch it on!

The new shell bar design for the SAP Business Suite is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The immediately visible difference is that now the product name is displayed to the right of the SAP Logo, in this case “S/4HANA Cloud” as you can see at the top of Figure 2. The logo and the name are all contained within a clickable area, which brings the user to the start page (e.g. My Home).

The new shell bar enables the next two design updates to the user menu and to notifications.

By default, after upgrading, the old shell bar will be shown, with the new navigation menu. We advise that you check any test automation and RPA (Robotic Process Automation) you may have before switching on the new shell bar, since you may need to make some adjustments – in particular if you log off at the end of a test.

You can switch on the new shell bar via the Activate New Features application, with the feature “/UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLE”.

Updated User Menu

The new user menu design shown in Figure 3 provides more space for the avatar of the user, and provides more space between items for easier selection. The settings are always at the top as the first entry, and the “Sign Out” option is separated from the actual navigation options in the list, to make it easier to find.

 Figure 3: Updated design of user menu and notifications. Alt Text: On the left an image of the previous user menu and the updated user menu. On the right an image of the updated notifications list, showing four notifications in the group “Last Month”, each with a title, two lines of description and a line with the data and a “more” link.

Updated Notifications Design

The new simplified design of notifications shown on the right in Figure 3 fits better with the overall design of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, and provides simpler interactions. By default notifications are sorted by date, with grouping by “Today”, “Yesterday”, “Last Week”, “Last Month”. Users can also choose to sort by importance.

New Illustrations Design

We have modernized the design of our illustrations, and also made them easier to understand. Figure 4 shows two examples – one for indicating that something went wrong (the fallen ice cream cone), one for search, with an example of where the search illustration is used when opening a list report application without any filter values defined.

 Figure 4: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing “search”. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

 

Web Access: My Home and SAP Fiori Launchpad

The 2025 release brings a number of improvements in My Home, the start page in the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as some improvements in the launchpad itself (beyond the design updates mentioned above) – for users as well as for administrators.

My Home

Here is an overview of the enhancements with this release:

  • To-Dos:
    • Tasks: Enhanced workflow relevant information and in-place actions
    • Situations from both standard and extended framework- are displayed
  • Intelligent homepage experience to boost productivity (cloud only):
    • Intelligent app recommendations.
    • Intelligent generation of pre-delivered cards.
  • Improved user experience: 
    • Drag & drop is now enabled in the insights section, so you can directly rearrange your tiles and cards.
    • Information about deprecated apps: any such apps are marked with an “deprecated2 icon .
  • Manage News application.

 This collection of videos shows the individual features of My Home – both new and already existing ones:

  • My Home - Deep Dive (video collection)

Figure 5: My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and SAP S/4HANA2025. Alt Text: A screenshot showing all the sections of My Home: To-Dos with tabs for Tasks (selected) and Situations;, a row with News on the left and Pages showing 8 pages on the right; Apps, with tabs for Favorites (selected – showing 2 folders and 7 apps), Most Used, Recently Used, Recommended; Insight Tiles, showing 8 tiles; Insights Cards, showing 4 cards, 1 with a list and 3 with charts.

To-Dos Enhancements

The To-Dos task cards now offer action buttons, for example to approve or reject items. Often, this requires some key information about the item, for example the name of the product and the value for a purchase requisition. These details are now visualized directly in the task cards, as you can see in Figure 5, making the workflow more efficient.

To-Dos now also shows custom Situations, created using the extended Situation Handling framework, in addition to the standard situations delivered by SAP.

Intelligent Homepage Experience

Another useful new feature is AI recommendations for applications: as you can see in Figure 5 in the Apps section of My Home, a new tab Recommended has been introduced which uses AI to create a list of applications which are recommended to the user to add to their Favorites.

To help users get started with My Home, we provide intelligent generation of pre-delivered cards, so that when they first log on, the Insights Cards section is not blank, but rather has a number of pre-delivered cards relevant to the user’s role.

Manage News Application

I’m glad to announce that administrators can now easily create their own news to be displayed on My Home, using the new Manage News application. Figure 6 shows the start page of the application, listing news articles.

You can specify title, subtitle and main text, a background image, the start and end dates for publishing, as well as categorizing and targeting the news for specific groups of users. Also, you can mark a news article as being “Critical”, so that it is highlighted accordingly. You can see an example in Figure 5.

Figure 6: Manage News application. Alt Text: Screenshot of the Manage News application, showing a filter bar and a list of two news articles with their title, subtitle, footer text, criticality, status “published” and publish start and end dates.

To get a better impression of how it works, watch this video:

  • Video: Manage News Application in My Home for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (2:00 min.)

You can find out more about these My Home innovations here:

  • My Home documentation.

SAP Fiori Launchpad

The launchpad provides more than just the spaces and pages for finding and starting apps: it provides the runtime shell in which all the applications run, and hence the updates mentioned above such as the new navigation, the new shell bar and user menu. It also controls navigation between apps, as well as settings such as which theme to apply. Here are some additional improvements with the 2025 release. 

Automatic high-contrast and dark-mode detection, also for custom themes

Users can define on their front-end device’s operating system whether applications should appear in a light mode or a dark mode, or a high-contrast mode. Now these settings are taken into account also for custom themes, in addition to SAP visual themes.

Technically this is done by the launchpad supporting theme sets, which is a group of themes of the same family with different flavors – such as the Horizon theme, with a light and dark version along with high contrast black and high contrast white versions. Customers can create their own theme sets using the UI theme designer. Have a look at the documentation:

  • Managing Your Settings (see the setting Appearance).

Hiding empty pages and spaces

The apps which a user sees on a page on the SAP Fiori launchpad, and the pages which appear in a space, depend on a user’s authorizations. This can lead to a page being defined in such a way that certain users are not authorized to use any of the apps therein; similarly, a space can end up not having any pages available to a user. Now, if this happens, any such empty pages or spaces are hidden from the user, rather than being shown empty. Find out more here:

  • SAP Fiori launchpad: Hiding empty spaces and pages.

Improved About Dialog for Application Information

We have simplified the about screen, organizing it into separate tabs for Application, System and Environment information, so that there is a clear separation between the different types of information – see it in action in Figure 7:

Figure 7: New About dialog. Alt Text: A short video showing the list view of the Manage Sales Orders – Version 2 app. The user opens the user settings menu in the shell header bar, selects “about”, and a popover appears with the same design as the user settings, showing three separate tabs listed vertically on the left for “Application”, “System” and “Environment”, with “Application” the default. Application shows title and ID of the app, along with framework version; System shows the product, system and tenant name; Environment shows the client device type and user agent details.

Update for Administrators of SAP Fiori Launchpad

Redesign of Apps for Managing Spaces and Pages

Up until now, the apps “Manage Launchpad Spaces” and “Manage Launchpad Pages” distinguished between entries which could be edited within a given tenant and entries which could only be used as templates when creating new spaces or pages. The editable ones were listed in the tab “Customer-Created”, the others in the tab “Predefined”.

Our customers gave us feedback that this was in fact confusing, because a page which was listed as “Customer-Created” in a non-productive tenant and which was transferred to a productive tenant became “Predefined” there, i.e. it was not listed under “Customer-Created” despite it being customer-created.

Now, the design has been changed, with two tabs for editable entities (spaces or pages) and non-editable ones. For example, in the app “Manage Launchpad Pages”, the tabs are called “Pages” and “Page Templates”, as shown in Figure 8. No matter what tenant you are in, you cannot change or edit page templates, you can only use them to create new pages. The same applies to spaces in the Manage Launchpad Spaces app.

Figure 8: The redesigned app Manage Launchpad Pages with Tabs for “Pages” and “Page Templates”. Alt Text: image shows an extract of the app showing the two tabs.

Role-dependent Launchpad Configuration Parameters

We provide administrators a new option to apply launchpad settings role-based, so that different roles can have different settings being applied. This can be helpful if a specific group of users need different settings, for example if you want to gradually introduce Spaces and Pages, you no longer have to switch it on for all users. Find out more, and further examples, in the documentation:

  • Setting Parameters per Profile

 

Mobile Access: SAP Mobile Start

The recent innovations I would like to highlight here are directly relevant for users accessing SAP S/4HANA directly:

  • Personalization
  • News – now with images and top news
  • Document AI
  • Joule for Mobile (covered in the section on Joule further below)

Personalizing SAP Mobile Start

For a good and satisfying user experience, being able to personalize the UI so that it fits with how you like to work is a key element. To this end, SAP Mobile Start has now introduced personalization of the start page, allowing you to rearrange the order of sections as well as hiding sections which you don’t need – take a look at it in Figure 9.

Figure 9: SAP Mobile Start personalization of the start screen. Alt Text: Four mobile phone images. On the left the start page, with the sections Insights and News visible. Next, an image of the edit screen, with five sections listed: Latest To-Dos, Favorites, Insights, App Suggestions (deselected), News. Next, an image of the five sections, all selected, now with Favorites first and Latest To-Dos second. On the right, the start page with the sections Favorites at the top (containing flat cards for apps), below that Latest To-Dos (containing larger cards for ToDos, one shocing a purchase requisition with Total Amount $799.99).

News with Images and Top News

News can now include images. Furthermore, we have also introduced Top News – news that is so important to users, that it is shown prominently on the Start Screen. You can see examples of top news with an image as well as regular news with images in Figure 10. For more information, check out the

  •  SAP Mobile Start Administration Guide (documentation).

Figure 10: News with images, including Top News. Alt Text: Two mobile phone images shown, on the left the start page with Top News at the top, with an article and an image; below that sections for Favorites and Latest To-Dos. On the right a list of five news articles with text on the left and an image on the right.

Document AI Integrated into SAP Mobile Start

With the integration with SAP Document AI, users can scan or upload documents directly from SAP Mobile Start, which are then processed by the SAP Document AI service. So, if you for instance need to scan and upload a quality certificate, you can start the upload process right from SAP Mobile Start, and the SAP Document AI service takes care of all needed follow-up steps, like extracting the data and assigning it to the right business objects.  

Figure 11: Screenshots of SAP Mobile Start with SAP Document AI. Alt Text: 3 mobile phone images: on the left the start screen, in the middle a screen Select Document Type, with choices Standard Delivery Note (selected) and Supplier or Procurement quality certificates, on the camera showing an document, with a Save button.

 Find further information and a detailed step by step guide on how to setup SAP Document AI service within SAP Mobile Start here:

  • New in SAP Mobile Start V2.4: Integrate and Launch SAP Document AI on Mobile. 

Further Innovations and Information on SAP Mobile Start

SAP Mobile Start has further innovations related to integrating with SAP Build Work Zone, such as supporting spaces and pages from its new site experience, supporting its declarative UI integration cards, or supporting integration with the advanced edition.

To find out more about all the recent innovations as well as what is planned in our road map, have a look at:

  • SAP Mobile Start V2.0 - Release Update
  • Joule on Mobile & Start Screen Personalization: SAP Mobile Start V2.1 - Release Update
  • Support of SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and much more: SAP Mobile Start V2.2 & 2.3 - Release Update.
  • SAP Mobile Start V2.4: SAP Document AI integration and much more. Release Update.
  • SAP Mobile Start Road Map.

 

Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP’s cloud products, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access them and providing a nice flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, we’ll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations in the web and mobile, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities.

Cross-Product Joule UX Innovations

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Analytical Pattern.
  • Joule supports multiple conversations.
  • Use Joule in 11 languages.
  • Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams
  • Customer specific skills and agents.

Joule Analytical Pattern

This new pattern is available in all products which give users access to our Joule copilot. This new pattern is powered by SAP Analytics Cloud, with data from models that are indexed by the Just Ask feature of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Figure 12: Example Joule Analytical Pattern. Alt Text: an animated GIF showing how a user asks Joule “Show me sales commission by agend for model bike sales”, and how Joule shows a horizontal bar chart for top 5 sales commissions per sales agent.

As you can see in figure 12, users can now access analytical insights from the product they are working in, without having to first navigate to SAP Analytics Cloud, making work more efficient and hence also more enjoyable.

The example in figure 12 is what we call a descriptive question, but Joule can respond to a wide range of queries:

  • Descriptive questions, such as “What is the total revenue for Q1?” or “Show me sales by region in 2025”.
  • Comparative analysis, such as “Compare sales between 2023 and 2024" Or How do profits in Germany compare to France?”
  • Time series analysis, such as “Show me sales by month” or “Show the trend of customer acquisitions over the last 6 months”.
  • Top / Bottom N analysis, such as “Show me top 5 sales by store” or “List the bottom 3 regions in terms of sales”.

Find out more in this blog post:

  • Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly.

With the introduction of this new pattern, Joule now supports four interaction patterns:

  1. Informational pattern, for querying written documents, such as SAP documentation in the SAP Help Portal, or customer policies etc.
  2. Navigational pattern, for finding and navigating to applications.
  3. Transactional pattern, for interacting directly with business applications.
  4. Analytical pattern, for answering analytical queries directly in Joule.

Joule Supports Multiple Conversations

When having a conversation with Joule, you can ask follow-up questions, building on the previous questions and answers in the conversation, since Joule keeps the context.

Now you can initiate up to ten conversations in parallel, with Joule keeping the context for each of the conversations, so that when you return to a previous conversation you can continue where you left off. Figure 13 shows what this looks like.

Figure 13: Joule supports multiple conversations. On the left, a conversation was started by asking “How many languages does Joule support”. On the right, you see how active and expired conversations are shown. Alt Text: On the left, Joule replies with “Joule currently supports eleven language officially” and then lists them, below the answer a link to the source document “Joule Multi Language Support” is provided. On the right, the conversation history sidebar is visible on the left, overlaying half the screen, with a button “+ New Conversation” at the top, followed by a section “Active” with two conversations and a section “Expired” with four. The bottom contains a link to “Settings” and on to “AI Notice”.

 You can return to conversations within 8 hours. To start a new conversation, simply click on “New Conversation”. The old conversation will be listed in the “Active” section, as you can see in Figure 13. The title of the conversation is automatically created by Joule using AI; users can rename the titles when they return to the conversation.  Joule supports a maximum of 10 active conversations.

After 8 hours, the conversation expires but is not deleted. It is kept read-only in the “Expired” section, as shown in Figure 13. Conversations are finally deleted 7 days after the creation date.

In the browser, Joule can be expanded to fill the screen, as shown in Figure 14.

Figure 14: Joule expanded to full-screen mode, showing the conversation history sidebar and the chat side by side. Alt Text: The same information is shown as on both screens of Figure 2, since the conversation history sidebar does not overlay the chat, and the chat is shown on the right with much more screen width.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • Using the Joule Web Client.

Use Joule in 11 Languages

Figure 14 shows that you can ask Joule which languages it supports, and it will answer with the list of 11 languages. Here they are in alphabetical order, with the variant of the language in brackets.

  • Chinese (Simplified)
  • English (US)
  • French (France)
  • German (Germany)
  • Greek
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Polish
  • Portugese (Brazil)
  • Spanish (Spain)
  • Vietnamese 

Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams

How often have you been in a chat with a colleague and needed to find some information from an SAP system? Up until now this would involve you leaving the chat, going to a different window and navigating to the right SAP application to get what were looking for.

Now, you can chat directly with Joule in Microsoft Teams, use Joule in Microsoft Teams and Microsoft Teams Mobile as an app, and ask Joule questions directly in Microsoft 365 Copilot. To get an idea of how powerful this is, watch this video:

To get started, have a look at the documentation:

  • Integrating Joule with Microsoft 365 Copilot

Joule Available on Mobile

Joule is also now generally available for mobile, running natively with SAP Mobile Start. It is now also available integrated in the SAP apps SAP SuccessFactors and SAP Sales Cloud. Figure 1 shows examples of Joule running on a mobile phone.

Figure 15: Examples showing Joule integrated in SAP Mobile Start, showing from left to right: the start page, the informational pattern accessing SAP Help Portal, and the transactional pattern used to interact with SAP S/4HANA Cloud and then with SAP SuccessFactors. ALT Text: Four images are shown: the start page shows a “How can I help you” text, followed by some suggested prompts as buttons; the informational pattern shows the prompt “How can I customize a sales order”. Below that, the sixteen-line written answer is shown, followed by a “Search results” selector and three top search results. The navigational pattern shows the prompt “Show sales orders with delivery status not completed”, below that, the reply from Joule “Here’s what I’ve found” is followed by a card containing three lines and an “Open” button. A second transactional example with the prompt “Show profile of Maria Alvares”, followed by the result and a button for navigating to her profile.

On Apple devices you can now use Siri and Siri Shortcuts to seamlessly start a conversation with Joule - which even works better with Apple Intelligence. Simply say "Hey Siri, ask SAP. Show my sales orders with delivery status not completed" and Joule will provide you with the respective content within the app.

Note that as of today, not all your prompts and web apps are supported on the phone; however, we are continuously adding further Joule business skills and scenarios.

Find out more here:

  • Joule on Mobile & Start Screen Personalization: SAP Mobile Start V2.1 - Release Update

Product-specific capabilities

In addition to the above generic capabilities, we provide Joule skills for getting your work done more efficiently, for specific use cases. Find out more about these in the SAP Discovery Center and in the documentation:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, Joule (SAP Discovery Center).
    Here you’ll also find links to many further resources.
  • Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (Documentation).

Customer-specific Joule skills and agents

You can now build your own Joule skills and beta-test agents using Joule Studio, which has now been made generally available. Read Michael Ameling’s overview blog post:

  • Joule Studio is generally available in SAP Build: Empower your business with intelligent automation

Joule Agents

We are bringing SAP Business AI to the next level via Joule Agents, that can autonomously plan and execute multi-step workflows.

Why do I include this in a section on user experience updates? Aren’t Joule Agents a back-end thing? Well… the reason is simple: Joule Agents significantly enhance the overall user experience, as opposed to the user interface, because the system will do a lot more for you based on your requests. This means that the overall experience you have using SAP goes up a level, since you can get a lot done much more easily than before.

Joule Agents can be triggered from Joule directly or embedded within applications.

For a general overview of Joule Agents, have a look here:

  • Joule Agents on sap.com.
  • AI Agents in Action (blog post).
  • Envision the Future of Generative AI with SAP's AI Agents (blog post).
  • How SAP’s AI Agent Architecture Enables Unprecedented Automation and Decision Augmentation (blog post by Philipp Herzig).

 

Intelligent Situation Handling news

Intelligent Situation Handling speeds up the resolution of critical business situations by automatically and hence proactively alerting users about urgent issues, proposing follow-up actions, letting you monitor situations, and automating the resolution by using business rules.

If you’re not familiar with Intelligent Situation Handling, I recommend that you watch the introductory video and read the “Get started” blog posts on the SAP Community topic page:

  • Intelligent Situation Handling topic page.

 With the 2025 release, SAP provides nine new situation templates in the areas of finance, public sector, service, sourcing and procurement, and supply chain:

  • New use cases for Situation Handling.

 For the full list of available templates provided by SAP, look here:

  • Use Cases for Situation Handling.

New Situation Handling Framework Capabilities

Already with the 2023 release we made it possible for partners and customers to create their own situation objects with ABAP Development Tooling (ADT) via developer extensibility. This becomes even more powerful with the 2025 release, with the extended framework supporting the collection of data context, support for custom objects in your own use cases, and support for the standard translation option. Let’s have a look at these in a bit more detail.

Data Context supported by the Extended Framework

The data context is business data from business objects involved in a situation instance that can be collected, distributed, and used for advanced analytics – for example using the Monitor Situations – Extended app. If enabled in a situation type, data context is collected when a situation instance is created, updated, or completed. For example, If you use the situation template Quantity Deficit in Supplier's Delivery to inform specific members in your purchasing organization about a deficit in the quantity of materials to be delivered by the supplier, you'll get, for example, the material, plant, or supplier as part of the data context.

With the 2025 release, every extended object-based situation template supports data context. You can activate it in the Manage Situation Types - Extended app. Doing so results in an event being triggered that includes the data context every time a situation instance is created, updated or completed. For more information, look at the documentation:

  • Data Context (documentation).
  • Data Context in the What’s New documentation.

Custom Object Types Supported

You can now use custom object types and object node types, that you have created with the ABAP development tools for Eclipse (ADT), in situation objects in the Manage Situation Objects app as well as in ADT. Until now, you could only use those delivered by SAP. Hence you have far more flexibility in supporting your own Situation Handling use cases.

Translation with Standard Function Supported

With this feature, you can use the standard function for translating texts included in situation objects, situation scenarios, and situation types. This means that you now can use the Maintain Translations app, so that all your translation work can be done in a consistent way now. Find out more in the documentation:

  • Translate Texts from Situation Objects, Situation Scenarios, and Situation Types.

 

AI-Assisted Capabilities: Outlook

 We have introduced a number of AI-assisted capabilities in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, as presented in my blog post SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad, in particular:

  • AI-assisted enterprise search.
  • AI-assisted easy filter.
  • AI-assisted smart summarization.
  • AI-assisted financial business insights.

 These are currently on our road map for delivery in Q4/2026 for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. Please not that, as usual with such forward-looking statements, our plans are subject to change.

 If you look at the above public cloud blog post, you might also notice the new Salutation Bar and the Recap feature in My Home. These are also currently on the road map for delivery in Q4/2026.

 

New Collaboration Capabilities

Collaborative Draft

Some selected applications support collaborative draft handling of business objects. This means that more than one user can edit a business object, such as a payment advice, at the same time, and see changes made by others before the object is finally saved.

 Within the object page, the object header shows the avatars of those who are editing; you also get the avatar shown next to fields which they are editing. Also, we have extended the grid table to indicate which entries are currently in a draft state, as well as showing those currently being edited by someone else (see Figure 16); this is also available in the responsive tables.

 You can invite other users to join you in working on an object, as you can also see in Figure 16.

Figure 16: Collaborative draft. On the top left you see how you can invite colleagues to edit the draft with you. The image on the right shows how you can see who else is editing the object, in this case “Payment Advice”, and which field they are currently editing. On the bottom left you can see the new indicators in grid tables. Alt Text: three screenshots are shown as described, the names of the colleagues editing are shown as pop-overs.

 Collaborative draft utilizes the latest SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 technology.

To-Dos in Microsoft Teams

Important notifications should not go unnoticed, so we help to ensure that by providing an additional way for users to be notified about To-Dos from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Tasks and Situations which are shown on My Home can now also pushed to users via Microsoft Teams, where they show up as new activities. Figure 17 shows how tasks are integrated. As you can see, not only are users notified directly in Teams, they also get direct access to their task embedded in Teams and can take direct action, such as approve or reject a request.

Figure 17: Tasks appearing as activities in Microsoft Teams. ALT Text: The “Activity” tab in Microsoft Teams is shown , with a list showing on the left one activity “New tasks in SAP S/4HANA – There is 1 new task for you – ToDos” and on the right embedded within Teams the screen from My Inbox, showing the header data plus a list of Items and Bidders, and action buttons at the bottom for Approve, Reject, Show Log, Claim, Forward and Suspend.

 See it in action here:

  • Video: To-Dos in Microsoft Teams (1:00 min.)

 In addition to being able to process To-Dos for tasks directly in Microsoft Teams, you can also process To-Dos for Business Situations directly in Microsoft Teams.

This means that you get notified in your Teams activity feed about new Business Situations, and you can process Business Situations in place, without having to leave Teams, as you can see in Figure 18.

Figure 18: To-Dos for Business Situations are available via Activities in Microsoft Teams. Alt Text: Two screenshots are shown, the top one shows an row of Situation cards in My Home, the bottom one shows the Activity view in Teams, with the activity “Situations in SAP S/4HANA” and sub-text “There are 9 situations for you” selected on the left, and the right two thirds of the screen showing a list with the same situations as shown in My Home.

To enable this, you need to install the SAP S/4HANA for Microsoft Teams app.

For further information:

  • Documentation: Integrating Microsoft Teams.

Contact Cards Show Contact’s Availability Status

Since FPS02 of the 2023 release, users can initiate a chat or call with Microsoft Teams directly from a contact card. I featured this in my previous blog post, look at Figure 5 there for two examples:

  • SAP User Experience Q4/2024 News for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023.

Now, with the 2025 release, this has been enhanced to show the availability status of the contact as provided by Teams.

Share as Card via Adaptive Card-based Loop Component

We now offer the option to enable embedding of interactive cards with information and actions from SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP S/4HANA directly into Microsoft Teams chats. The data and actions are only shown to users with the necessary authorizations. Technically this is done via adaptive card-based Loop component, for applications built with SAP Fiori elements. Figure 19 shows an example.

Figure 19: An example of an adaptive card embedded in a Teams chat. Alt Text: A screenshot of a chat, with a request text to Megan at the top, followed by a URL to access the app, and then a card showing a purchase contract, with the text Quantity Contract as a hyperlink, along with 9 further fields from the contract. At the bottom clickable buttons “Copy” and “Withdraw from Approval”.

 Find out more, including how to set it up:

  • Integrating the Share: Microsoft Teams > As Card – Authentication-Enabled Option (documentation).

UX Improvements in Details

As I never tire of saying: the details matter if you want to provide a great UX! We continue to work on these details, which can often result in higher satisfaction for users. With the 2025 release, we bring you a large number of improvements, as outlined in the following subsections. Note that we have four interesting ones related to working with tables towards the end of this section.

New Options for Filtering Dates (Semantic Date Range)

We have two new features here:

  • We now offer the semantic date range also for selecting dates in the table settings dialog, if you want to define a specific filter on a given field in the table. (Note that the table settings dialog allows you to define filters on all the fields in the table, irrespective of which fields appear in the filter bar at the top of the screen).
  • I’m pleased to say that, on request of many users, we now provide the option to define filters on date fields for the “Last X days/weeks/months/… to date” as well as the “Next X days/weeks/months/… to date”, where users can specify the number “X”.

An example of how tricky such seemingly simple things can be: if, on December 11th, you choose “Last 2 months to date”, do you mean the period from November 1st to December 11th, which would be up to the current date but not a full two months, or do you mean “the last two full months”, i.e. October 1st to November 30th? Since both make sense, the selection screen gives users the option to choose, with the default being the “full month” case, described as “exclude current period”, as you can see in Figure 20.

Column Size Persisted in Flexible Column Layout

When users open up an application which uses the Flexible Column Layout, it will now remember where the user had placed the separator last time, rather than putting it in the default position. Figure 21 shows an example where at the top you see the default position, and below you see the separator moved to the right slightly, so that all the text is visible in the table on the left. Next time the app is opened, the separator will open in the same place.

Figure 21: Flexible Column Layout now remembers the previously used column width. The image at the top shows the default column width, the image below shows the last column width the user chose. Alt Text: two images of Manage Cost Centers application is shown, the upper one has the separator bar between the list on the left and the details on the right further to the left than the image on the right.

All Data Dictionary Help Texts Available to Users

This feature was requested by many customers, and I am happy to announce that it is now available: all the help texts for individual fields which are stored in the back-end data dictionary are now available to users using the built-in help, powered by SAP Companion. In other words, users of SAP Fiori apps have access to the same help texts as were shown with the classic UIs such as SAP GUI. You can see an example in Figure 22.

Figure 22: Data Dictionary help texts now available in SAP Fiori apps. Alt Text: The Manage Purchase Contracts screen is shown, with question marks next to all fields and column headers. On the right the Help Topics are listed, with the Purchase Contract Number selected. Next to the corresponding column header a popover shows the definition text.

Documentation of Keyboard Shortcuts within Applications

Power users are often quicker when only using the keyboard, rather than switching back and forth between keyboard and mouse – but only if they know all the relevant keyboard shortcuts. With the 2508 release we provide information about available keyboard shortcuts directly where you need them, in the context of the application. By selecting “Keyboard Shortcuts” in the user menu, a new window appears explaining all the available shortcuts for the application area currently in focus. If you click on a different part of the application, or navigate somewhere else, then the window showing the available shortcuts is updated immediately for the new context.

Figure 23 shows an example for Manage Journal Entries, where the focus is currently on the filter bar. Clicking on the the table results in many more shortcuts being shown, for example for the arrow keys for moving up and down etc., as shown in Figure 24.

Figure 23: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the filter bar. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app “Manage Journal Entries” with the focus on the filter bar, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, “Global Shortcuts” and “Generic Keyboard Interactions”.

Figure 24: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the table. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app “Manage Journal Entries” with the focus on the table, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, “Global Shortcuts” and “Journal Entries (43,854)”. The latter contains descriptions for shortcuts for the table, such as the arrow up, down, left, right keys, or using “Cmd + D” to delete.

Automatic Update of SAP Fiori Apps Upon Change of Data in Backend

There are quite a few cases where users would appreciate seeing absolutely up-to-date data in their application, so that the data is automatically updated if changes occur in the backend. These changes could be made by other users, or by automated background processing . An example for the latter is the Traceability Results application, which is now automatically updated if a batch run has created new traceability items.

Note that this only supported by applications built with SAP Fiori elements using OData V4.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time – magic!

Figure 25: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 25. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 26 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The “Threshold” determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the “Scroll Threshold” determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 26: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over “Configure Table” with two new fields “Threshold”, being edited with the value 3000, and “Scroll Threshold”, containing the value 300.

Table Grouping and/or “Show more per row” State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleague: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see the same grouping applied.

Similarly, if “show more per row” was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 27, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry “1710 (BestRun US)”, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is “BestRun US”. In the popover “Sort By” section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 27: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over “Column Settings” with two sections “Sort By” and “Group By”. The “Sort By” section has two lines, “Company Code” and “Company Name”, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing “no sorting”, “ascending”, “descending”.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 28), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 28: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over “View Settings” containing tabs “Columns”, “Sort”, “Filter”, and a pop-over “Filters” with two options “Hide descriptions” (selected) and “Hide Unselected” (deselected) . “Columns” is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is “Company Code”, followed by “Created On” – i.e. the description column “Company Name” is not listed next to the “Company Code”.

These are the highlights of our changes in details. For the full list of what’s new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the What’s New Viewer:

  • What’s New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UI adaptation improvements for key users

We have made significant enhancements to UI Adaptation for key users with the 2025 release. The “Adapt UI” option which key users see in their user menu shows you what you can change in the app, in a very intuitive way. And you can change and adapt far more than in the past. See below for some highlights.

Also good to know: the Adapt UI menu entry is also available when using a Classic app (SAP GUI for HTML) from within the SAP Fiori launchpad. It will bring up the Adapt UI app for Screen Personas F5740 Adapt UI for Classic Applications with Screen Personas, which allows key users to adapt the layout of these classic UIs.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example “1710 (BestRun US)” as shown in Figure 27. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example “US Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)” as shown in Figure 2.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Far More Options for Key Users to Adapt UIs

Key users can now make far more significant changes to UIs than before. For example, they can add a button to clear all filter values in the filter bar, remove buttons such as the “Export to Excel”, and much more. Figure 29 shows the options for configuring a table for example.

Figure 29: Many more options for Key Users to adapt UIs. Alt Text: UI Adaptation is shown switched on for the application Manage Bank Hierarchies, with a popover called “Configure Table” filling half the screen, and showing 12 options such as “Enable Table Export”, “Frozen Column Count” with a field for entering the number, “Sorting”, “Columns” etc.

 

Design and Technology News

For a comprehensive overview of the recent design and technology news, have a look at my blog posts from Q1 and Q3 2025. These are also relevant for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025 release, since the design and technology are already available in the cloud:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update – Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
    Note though that the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard presented there is currently only integrated with for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

We are progressing at such a pace, that I have some additional news to share with you, not covered by the above posts. In addition, I would like to explicitly mention some particular highlights here from the above posts too.

Regarding extensibility: do have a look at the new SAP Extensibility Explorer.

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits – now with AI Components

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

We have just released SAP Web UI Kit v8.0 which includes a full set of AI components: AI Button, AI Menu Button, AI Split Menu Button, AI Prompt Input, AI Input, AI Text Area, and AI Rich Text Editor.

Figure 30: The SAP Design System portal start page (on the left), and SAP’s UI Kits for designers in Figma (on the right). Alt Text: Two screenshots. The portal page shows four main sections SAP Fiori for Web, … for Android, … for iOS, and SAP Digital Design System, each followed by links to UI elements, Figma kits, and overviews. The UI Kits show 8 cards, SAP Fiori for Android, Web, iOS, watchOS, Wear OS, Performance, Accessibility and SAP S/4HANA.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

SAP Fiori Development Portal

I’m also happy to inform you about the new SAP Fiori development portal, introduced a few weeks ago. It is designed to help developers maximize the benefits of SAP Fiori elements for OData V4, which is more than just a UI framework: it’s a metadata-driven approach that leverages the SAP Design System as its guiding principle, incorporating the most relevant design system options for typical business tasks.

Figure 31: The SAP Fiori development portal. Alt text: A screenshot showing the Introduction page. On the left a menu has entries Using the Portal, Building Blocks, Global Patterns, Floorplans, SAP Fiori Tools. The Introduction page has a full width card “Building Blocks” at the top, with a description and tiles representing various building blocks. Below that “Choose Your Option” heading above two side-by-side cards for “Floorplans” and “Customer Layout”, each with an image and description, and a “Learn More” button.

The SAP Fiori development portal puts building blocks front and center. These building blocks - such as tables, forms, filter bars, and charts - are orchestrated by SAP Fiori elements and form the basis of every OData V4 application. They provide standardized layouts and interaction patterns, ensuring UI consistency and boosting developer productivity. The great advantage of using building blocks is that you can use them to create a customer layout and yet still benefit from the advantages of the metadata driven approach: low code, built in enterprise-grade capabilities such as multi-language support, accessibility, security and performance, and design system consistency.

Find out more in this six-part series of blog posts, here is the first one, which contains links to the others:

  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6).

Using AI to Develop UIs

The above posts from Q1/2025 and Q3/2025 introduced a number of powerful ways to accelerate UI development by using AI, such as:

  • Creating SAP Fiori elements apps from a sketch (in the Q1 post), now integrated in SAP Build Code and Joule (Q3 post)
  • Joule for SAPUI5 freestyle development (Q1 post)
  • AI-assisted auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter (Q3 post)

Recently, we have gone even further and introduced MCP servers for freestyle SAPUI5 development as well as for developing with SAP Fiori elements and the associated building blocks. These open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers provide AI agents with comprehensive UI5 and SAP Fiori elements knowledge, including best practices and project-aware context information, and thus provide developers with valuable support. Figure 32 shows examples. 

Figure 32: Examples of the UI5 MCP Server (on the left) and the MCP Server for SAP Fiori (on the right) in action. Alt Text: both images show screenshots of a CLINE console view with a task entered as text at the top, followed by a list of steps which the system proposes to do to solve the task.

 Read about these new MCP servers in these blog posts:

  • UI5 MCP Server.
  • MCP Server for SAP Fiori.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users don’t accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging – so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2 

Blue Crystal and Belize Themes No Longer Available in the Web

As announced in April (Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal), the visual themes Blue Crystal and Belize have been removed from our web UI technology with the 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

 After upgrading, existing usages of Belize or Blue Crystal will be automatically redirected to the Horizon theme.

If you have created your own custom theme based on Belize or Blue Crystal using the UI theme designer, you will need to migrate this to an available theme. Our strong recommendation is to base the new version on the Horizon theme.

For more information about the web UI technologies affected, and how to migrate custom themes, have a look at this blog post:

  • Announcement: Removal of Belize theme of SAP Fiori.

Note that SAP GUI for Windows continues to support older themes, including Blue Crystal and Belize.

 

Final words

Come join us at TechEd 2025, November 4 - 6, either virtually or in Berlin, or at one of the TechEd On The Road events in Louisville (USA), Bangalore (India) and Sydney (Australia), to find out more about our latest user experience innovations. I myself will be in Berlin and Bangalore, so feel free to approach me after my talks if you have any specific questions. I’m looking forward to meeting some of you!

 This blog posts gives an overview of all the UX related sessions at all four events:

  • Exciting UX talks at TechEd – Virtual, or meet us in Berlin and On The Road (USA, India, Australia).

 Please continue using the community to share your learnings and best practices, either by posting articles yourselves or via comments on this post. You can also follow me in the community if you want to be notified about further similar updates from me.

entry.title: JOIN US: Meet SAP HANA Cloud @ SAP TechEd 2025
entry.content:
Hi there! If you care about turning data into real business advantage, this one’s for you. TechEd airs next Tuesday, and our SAP HANA Cloud track is built to spark ideas, answer your toughest database and AI questions, and get you hands-on with the tools you’ll use tomorrow. Join us in Berlin or online! We’d love to meet you!

🔹 Why this matters to you

  • If you’re responsible for data strategy, cloud architecture, or AI-enabled apps, SAP HANA Cloud is a central part of SAP’s Business Technology Platform and Business Data Cloud.
  • Expect practical takeaways: built-in AI capabilities, vector search and knowledge graphs, elastic compute for scale, and patterns for keeping your S/4HANA core clean while innovating fast.
  • This is more than theory — roadmap sessions and hands-on workshops show what’s coming in 2025 and beyond and how to apply it right away.

🔹 Meet the experts and join our sessions (onsite in Berlin — quick guide)

  • ST115 — Strategy Talk: “SAP HANA Cloud: The Database for Business AI”
    Nov 5, 2:15–2:40 PM CET
    A high-level look at how SAP HANA Cloud supports analytics, multi-model processing, ML and generative AI — and where we’re going next.
  • DA817 — Roadmap Session: “What’s Next for SAP HANA Cloud: Roadmap and Innovation Highlights”
    Nov 6, 1:30–1:55 PM CET
    Roadmap reveals: generative AI toolkit, tabular AI functions, and features to connect your data to AI agents.
  • DA200 — Deep Dive: “Help future-proof your database landscape with SAP HANA Cloud"
    Nov 5, 10:15–11:00 AM CET
    Architecture-focused deep dive: elastic compute, file-based architectures, knowledge graphs, and integration patterns, to prepare your data landscape for the future.
  • DA201 — Deep Dive: “Accelerating your AI strategy with SAP HANA Cloud”
    Nov 6, 9:00–9:45 AM CET
    How the In-Database AI, vector engine and knowledge graph engine enable context-rich AI scenarios via SAP HANA Cloud and SAP BTP.
  • DA202 — Deep Dive: “Extensibility at scale: Building intelligent applications with SAP HANA Cloud”
    Nov 5, 1:15–2:00 PM CET
    Real-world approaches to clean-core extensibility using CAP and SAP Build Code.
  • DA261 — Hands On: “Unlocking AI-driven insights from your business data in SAP HANA Cloud”
    Nov 4, 12:30–2:30 PM CET
    Hands-on focussing on working with tabular AI, similarity search, and RAG using the knowledge graph engine.
  • DA263 — Hands On: “SAP HANA Cloud: Advisors and Automation”
    Nov 6, 9:00–11:00 AM CET
    Try advisors and automation features (ECN provisioning, partition/index advisors) that reduce ops overhead.
  • DA262 — Hands On: “Enabling clean core development with SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Build Code”
    Nov 5, 3:30–5:30 PM CET
    Build side-by-side extensions with SAP HANA Cloud + CAP + SAP Build Code — fast, scalable, and safe.

🔹 Tune in for our virtual sessions

  • ST115v — Strategy Talk: “SAP HANA Cloud: The Database for Business AI”
    Nov 5, 6:30 - 6:55 PM CET
    A high-level look at how SAP HANA Cloud supports analytics, multi-model processing, ML and generative AI — and where we’re going next.
  • DA817v — Roadmap Session: “What’s Next for SAP HANA Cloud: Roadmap and Innovation Highlights”
    Nov 6, 1:30–1:55 PM CET
    Roadmap reveals: generative AI toolkit, tabular AI functions, and features to connect your data to AI agents.
  • DA201v — Deep Dive: “Accelerating your AI strategy with SAP HANA Cloud”
    Nov 6, 9:00–9:45 AM CET
    How the In-Database AI, vector engine and knowledge graph engine enable context-rich AI scenarios via SAP HANA Cloud and SAP BTP.

🔹 Who you’ll meet

Our speakers include engineers and product experts from the SAP HANA Cloud team, the people designing the roadmap and building the features you’ll use. Bring your toughest questions; these sessions are designed for real dialogue and practical guidance.

Curious now? A few questions you’ll leave with answers to:

  • How can genAI, knowledge graphs and agents change app behavior and search across enterprise data?
  • What does a vector & knowledge graph engine enable for RAG-style assistants?
  • How can elastic compute and automation lower costs and simplify scaling?
  • What are the best patterns to extend SAP apps without touching the core?

🔹 Onsite or virtual — your choice

TechEd supports both formats. If you’re in Berlin, come meet the team in person, network, ask questions, and join hands-on sessions. If you’re remote, register for the virtual stream and get the same deep content and access to speakers.

🔹 Next steps

Register now on the SAP TechEd registration page and add the SAP HANA Cloud sessions to your agenda.
If you want a hands-on slot, sign up early! Those sessions fill up fast.

 

See you in Berlin, or virtually! 🫶

entry.title: On-Premise Business AI Infrastructure for Small and Medium Enterprises Using NVIDIA DGX Spark
entry.content:
Disclaimer: this article is written without Generative AI, even for the proof reading 😊 Enjoy the article written by human that is not common nowadays

Why Business AI?

That is what we always must start with. The business case should go first, for sure, and then we should evaluate possible deployment options, costs and security.

Statistics says that 95% of Generative AI implementations failed and that really scares the market in SAP enterprise software domain as well.

But let’s be honest, we are trying to sell Business AI anywhere as technology, forgetting about the customers, their uniqueness and their current pain points.

At Skybuffer starting from February 2025 (during the last 9 months) we have talked to more than 250 customers of different sizes presenting them Business AI technologies and discussing their use cases, or better to say helping them to find how Business AI can help their employees and partners to automate company’s workflows.

There are three main groups of use cases, as we see it now:

  • Direct interaction with SAP backend system via corporate messengers that brings simplicity and mobility at the same time. In many cases Creating or Updating data in SAP from mobile phones or via Teams brings real value.
  • Converting any unstructured data to knowledge, like SharePoint sources, attachments in SAP, support tickets. Mixing those things together, in different document original languages create real value for employees providing them access to the data that is hidden in most of the organizations.
  • Capacity heavy activities delivered by AI agents, especially helpful with emails data analysis, where the main data is always in attachments. Sometimes it requires to utilize OCR extracting data from scanned PDFs in those scenarios. Some excellent examples are processing vendors emails and posting invoice or service entry sheets into SAP or receiving emails from customers converting their external purchasing data to sales orders.

That is why SAP customers with any SAP backend system, either SAP ECC or S/4HANA, can implement Business AI today. I am not saying that it covers the entire Business AI implementation benefits, however, that is what we are focusing on now and helping SAP customers to allocate the benefits of using the technology.

Costs

In our opinion, Business AI is close to being the tool that must be deployed inside IT infrastructure, but a technology that is to being considered only if it returns the investment. Think about the indirect impact of missing Business AI in your business landscape. For example, consider the costs of hiring new staff because your employees are moving to other companies that utilize modern technologies. Why should they move? Obvious, because of the same reason we are all talking about Generative AI – to stay competitive on the market.

However, costs of AI must be assessed carefully, because in most of the architecture approaches Business AI is a consumption-based solution. Risky, isn’t it? Of course! Consumption is hard to estimate, and it is also hard to avoid picks, so budgets of Business AI productive usage might be unacceptably high compared to the potential savings the technology brings. That is why we built Skybuffer AI as a solution with the double deployment options:

  • On premise, there is a clear and 100% predictable TCO.
  • On SAP BTP, this is a great option for CPEA contracts, for example, because in this case Business AI consumes the credits that are already paid, and we avoid extra costs for the infrastructure.

Why is DGX Spark in the article name?

Well, DGX Spark here is not because it is a buzz word now, for sure. That is because DGX Spark provides an excellent opportunity for small and medium enterprises to bring 15x15x12 cm GPU-unit to support their Business AI operations for a very compatible price. Actually, it allows us to keep both compute-unit and GPU-unit in the network avoiding data leakage and consumption-based costs. Excellent? Of course!

Here is how we use it deploying Skybuffer AI on premise:

Figure 01. Skybuffer AI deployment with GPU-unit served by DGX Spark

Criticism?

Yes, even writing this article I am already hearing the criticism 😊 Guessing the comments like, “that is not for productive environment”, “DGX Spark tokens generation too low to serve even Small businesses” and many other sharp negatives. But let’s move back to the beginning of the article and understand the reason why I’ve spent so much time talking about use cases first. Yes, now it is obvious that many mentioned use cases can be addressed by DGX Spark working as GPU-unit. Example? Easy!

Example #1: Vendor emails processing with data posting into SAP backend and saving originals (files) into the DMS (like SharePoint, Join, Google or whatever DMS is in use).

In the architecture mentioned above, Skybuffer AI allows almost out of the box creation of an AI Agent that will check, for example, Account Payable mailbox, read emails, analyze attachments, move them to DMS and create financial postings in SAP backend saving links to the attachments in DMS (either external or internal SAP DMS) on the SAP financial document level. In scenario, if we schedule the agent carefully, it can work in the almost synchronous 24/7 mode.

In case we schedule the Vendor Emails processing AI Agent with the limit to process just one vendor email in the minute, we will avoid pick system loads, and in this case, we can keep AI agent active 24/7. In such deployment it will be able to process 1 440 emails and create postings in SAP a day, that gives us 43 200 a month and amazing number of 518 400 documents a year!! All powered by one DGX Spark GPU-unit keeping the data on premise and avoiding cloud consumption.

That is what we call a proper deployment of Business AI. And Small and Medium businesses do not usually have such big number of documents from vendors, even the Cirque du Soleil does not have according to the latest SAP news post 😊 What we usually do, we add extra Business AI scenarios to be processed by the same Skybuffer AI deployment.

Example #2: Automation of SAP user management services

Small and Medium businesses do use password-based login to SAP backend, so users keep locking themselves or forgetting their passwords. Do we need a powerful GPU-unit with the full size LLM to automate this? No, for sure. We can add those business scenarios to the AI Agent that is processing Vendor Emails 😊

Example #3: Bank data reconciliation

The same setup can be used to assist financial department to match bank transactions to the billing documents in SAP and post accruals for the cases that could not be reconciled, for example, those that miss billing data in SAP that is not created just because someone has forgotten to enter it or integration interfaces have data processing issues. DGX Spark GPU-unit provides particularly good enough capacity here as well.

Those are just a few examples that wind away the skepticism about the utilization of DGX Spark in productive environment.

Is it safe to invest in the on-premise Business AI setup?

If you need full control over costs and data security, the answer is yes. And we think that the answer is yes in general, because Skybuffer AI dual deployment capabilities gives companies the guarantee that on premise Business AI investment can follow their potential future cloud strategy. I am writing and hearing again “what is this crazy man talking about! On premise investment can follow cloud strategies?? That is a paradox!”. And again, the answer is No, of course there is no paradox! If we look at the deployment of Skybuffer AI with integration with SAP Joule:

 Figure 02: Skybuffer AI deployment in SAP BTP with integration with SAP Joule

That is what we call real flexibility!

Sounds like a Gap Closing Solution?

Yes, that is the conclusion we have. There no hard choice anymore to run Business AI on premise or on SAP BTP, no prerequisites to start using Business AI, because the deployment in this article works with SAP ECC (down to 7.01 and even below), SAP S/4HANA on premise or SAP S/4HANA in private cloud. The only question must be asked, when we are talking about Business AI, is about the scenario the company should start with? You’ve seen in our examples that Business AI deployments might bring benefits working in the scenarios that are independent from the historical data you have in your SAP backend and the historical data quality (sometimes it is called data silos), or scenarios that are independent from the version of your system and the point in time of your current digital journey. No need to wait for the upgrades, migrations, or other activities that sound like an act of catching a tail 😊. Just allocate some budget for Business AI deployment, for example, on-premise deployment on DGX Spark that is very affordable, and get the positive feedback from your employees or business partners and enjoy your business workflows simplifications.

entry.title: How Redwood Software and SAP are shaping the next era of automation with Joule Studio
entry.content:
Introduction
